active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group debate, argue whether the right to data portability truly empowers individuals or creates undue burdens for organizations. Use real-world examples like social media data transfers (e.g., downloading Facebook data) and evidence from GDPR enforcement cases to support your position.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Data Subject Rights Implementation (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Asset Security > Information and Asset Handling > Compliance and Regulatory Requirements > Data Protection Regulations > Data Subject Rights Implementation). Use the provided learning objectives, active learning activities, 4-layer scaffolding, and flashcard schema to generate high-quality, pedagogically optimized flashcards. Incorporate: - All 8 GDPR rights fully (complete 'Right to object': objection to legitimate interest/direct marketing/research processing; sources: ico.org.uk, edpb.europa.eu). - Best practices: DSAR workflows, 1-month timelines, verification, challenges. - Comparisons: GDPR vs. CCPA/etc. - Concept map integration in explanations. Output ONLY a JSON array of flashcards, each as: {'id': 1, 'layer': 1-4, 'blooms_level': 'REMEMBER', 'right_covered': 'Access', 'type': 'MCQ', 'front': '...', 'back': '...', 'explanation': '...', 'distractors': ['opt1', 'opt2']}. Ensure distractors are plausible per schema. Aim for spaced repetition suitability: concise fronts, detailed backs/explanations. Total: 50 flashcards balanced per schema.
